The mathematical foundations of quantum theory are a major open problem in mathematics. The most promising approach is to use the language of category theory. However, the category of Hilbert spaces and bounded operators is not equivalent to the category of continuous linear operators on the other. We provide a set of axioms that guarantee the equivalence. The axioms are purely categorical and do not presuppose any analytical structure. This addresses a question about the foundations of quantum theory raised in reconstruction programs such as those of von Neumann, Mackey, Jauch, Piron, Abramsky, and Coecke.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic obligate parasites that cause diseases in a wide range of animals. The evolutionary origin of this group has been enigmatic, and a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies. Here, we present the first comparative genomic analysis of two distantly related myxozoan species, which show that the myxozoan body plan is reduced to the essential elements required for parasitism. Our results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic parasitic cnidarian was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. This study may help to understand the origin of the Myxozoa and the evolution of parasitism in general. (Show more)

COVID-19 is a global pandemic that has caused millions of deaths worldwide. The disease is caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2). The virus has a complex life cycle that involves multiple stages of infection. One of the most important stages is the infection of host cells. In this study, we show that SARS-CoV-2 is able to block nuclear import of STAT1 and STAT2, which are key components of the IFN-mediated antiviral signaling pathway. We found that the viral accessory protein Orf6 is responsible for this activity. Voltage-gated proton (Hv1) channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the dimeric Hv1. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels. Climate change will increase the variability of crop yields, making it more difficult to achieve global food security. Here, we quantify the impact of climate change on maize yields and variability in the major maize-producing and -exporting countries. We find that the variability of maize yields will increase substantially in most of these countries, and that the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year will increase. These results highlight the importance of investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

Large mammalian herbivores (LMH) are a dominant component of many ecosystems, and their grazing has been implicated in ecosystem functioning and biodiversity. However, the extent to which LMH partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level differences in diet. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant LMH species (six wild, one domestic) in semiarid African savanna. We found that LMH consumed a wide range of plant species, and that species were dissimilar in their diets. Nonetheless, species were not completely dissimilar, and dietary similarity was sometimes greater across guilds than within them. These results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in LMH assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. Our results also highlight the need for more comprehensive species-level diet data in future studies of LMH ecology and conservation. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We conducted a large-scale survey of small businesses to understand the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Many businesses are financially fragile, and those that survive the crisis will likely face a long road to recovery. We also find that many businesses are optimistic about the length of the crisis, which may lead to disappointment and disillusionment. Finally, we find that small businesses are likely to take advantage of the CARES Act, but many will face problems accessing the program.

Plastic debris is one of the most visible and controversial environmental problems of our time. The global distribution of floating plastic debris is still poorly understood. We show that the global load of plastic debris on the open ocean surface is far less than expected. This discrepancy is explained by the size distribution of the debris, which is dominated by small particles. These particles are rapidly removed from the surface by processes yet to be identified.

The origin of silicon carbide grains is still a matter of debate. We determined the ages of 40 large presolar silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. We find that a majority of the grains have ages of <300 Ma, which is shorter than theoretical estimates for large grains. This indicates that the grains condensed in outflows of asymptotic giant branch stars <4.9 Ga ago that possibly formed during an episode of enhanced star formation ∼7 Ga ago. A minority of the grains have ages of >1 Ga, which is longer than expected for large grains. We estimate that the majority of the grains acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium and not by exposure to an enhanced particle flux of the early active sun. This suggests that the grains were not exposed to a high particle flux for a long time. The results are important for the understanding of the formation of the solar system.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected oligodendrocytes. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn in a mouse model of MSA. This effect was associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn and with neuroprotection. These results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising candidate to slow down the progression of MSA. This would be of great importance as there is no treatment available to slow down the aggressive neurodegenerative process. Our results also suggest that caspase-1 could be a promising therapeutic target in synucleinopathies.

The endothelium is composed of a single layer of cells that are highly specialized to perform these functions. The endothelium is also responsible for controlling the contractility of the blood vessels and the formation of clots to control bleeding. The endothelium is composed of thousands of cells that are connected to each other by a network of connections. The network is designed to be both local and global in nature. The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges. We describe the design and implementation of the COVIDcast API, a data source that provides open access to a wide range of COVID-19 indicators, including many auxiliary signals that are not typically available in public health surveillance. These data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data are available through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. We provide examples demonstrating that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API present information relevant to tracking COVID activity, augmenting traditional public health reporting and empowering research and decision-making. The COVIDcast API is a resource that we hope will be useful to the public health community and beyond.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is critical for health and disease. The role of the gut microbiome in health and disease is becoming increasingly clear, but the mechanisms by which the microbiome regulates its own composition are less well understood. Here, we show that anaerobic fungi, which are members of the gut microbiome, synthesize a diverse array of natural products. These results support the hypothesis that anaerobic fungi are active participants in the regulation of the gut microbiome.

The hemoglobin system is a major determinant of the lifespan of the human organism. The hemoglobin system is also a major target of the let-7 miRNA pathway. Here we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is a downstream element of the let-7 pathway. We show that IGF2BP1 is developmentally regulated and that its expression is restricted to erythroid cells. We show that IGF2BP1 mediates posttranscriptional loss of the transcription factor BCL11A, which is a key regulator of fetal hemoglobin expression. These results suggest a mechanism for chronoregulation of fetal and adult hemoglobin expression in humans. This mechanism may be relevant to the evolution of the human organism. The most widely used drugs for treating hypertension are the L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs). However, the use of LCCBs is associated with the development of heart failure. Here, we show that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the management of 10 million hectares of federal forest in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP halted the decline of early-seral–associated bird populations, but the decline of older-forest–associated species accelerated. This is partly because of the loss of older forests due to fire on federal land and continued clearcutting elsewhere. The NWFP is a unique opportunity to evaluate the influence of policy. Our findings highlight the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure. This will be critical to achieving the NWFP’s goal of restoring biodiversity.

The design strategy is based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. We show that the best candidate designed by us is active against antibiotic-resistant pathogens and is up to 56 times more active than telithromycin. The design strategy is applicable to other antibiotic classes. The best candidate designed by us is a promising lead compound for further development. This article is protected by copyright. Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. Popular network architectures often add additional operations and connections to the standard architecture to enable training deeper networks. To achieve accurate results in practice, a large number of trainable parameters are often required. Here, we introduce a network architecture based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. Our results show that the proposed network architecture is a promising alternative to existing architectures. It is easier to implement, train, and apply in practice, and automatically adapts to different problems. It is also able to achieve state-of-the-art results in several segmentation problems.

The use of electronic devices for reading and entertainment has become increasingly popular in the past 50 y. However, the impact of such devices on sleep is unknown. Here we show that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device (LE-eBook) suppresses melatonin and has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety. These results have implications for the design of electronic devices and the timing of their use before bedtime.

CTLA-4 is a key regulator of immune responses, but its specific role in the development of autoimmunity is not known. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in adult mice. We found that CTLA-4 is required for the development of autoimmunity in a variety of organs, including the lung, gut, and salivary glands. Moreover, we show that CTLA-4 is required for the development of Treg cell-mediated suppression. These findings have important implications for the treatment of autoimmune diseases.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset of 89 genes to estimate the timing and rates of beetle diversification, and a dataset of 154 genomes or transcriptomes to trace the evolution of genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of lignocellulose. Phylogenomic analyses of these uniquely comprehensive datasets resolved previously controversial beetle relationships, and supported the codiversification of beetles and angiosperms. Moreover, corresponding (Jurassic) diversification rate increases suggest that these novel genes triggered adaptive radiations that resulted in nearly half of all living beetle species. We propose that these novel genes enabled efficient digestion of plant tissues, including lignocellulose in cell walls, facilitating the evolution of uniquely specialized plant-feeding habits, such as leaf mining and stem and wood boring. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV- concertantly across multiple variants. Our approach can be applied to other protein molecules and may be useful in the development of next-generation antibodies and vaccines. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work may help to reduce the burden of COVID-19.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of intense debate. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We manipulated population size such that participants could learn from the paper planes constructed by one, two, or four models from the prior generation. These social-learning conditions were compared with an asocial individual-learning condition in which individual participants made repeated attempts at constructing a paper plane, without having access to any planes produced by other participants. We found that larger populations generated greater variation in plane performance and gave participants access to better-adapted planes, but this did not enhance CCE. APOE is the strongest genetic risk factor for late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (AD). APOE isoform is also known to influence the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes, a process that is critical for normal brain function and is also disrupted in AD. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in controlling the rate of astrocytic phagocytosis of synapses. APOE2 enhances the rate of phagocytosis, whereas APOE4 decreases it. We also found that APOE4 increases the rate of C1q accumulation in hippocampus, which may represent the accumulation of senescent synapses with enhanced vulnerability to complement-mediated degeneration. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that APOE4 may be associated with AD risk in part because of defective astrocytic phagocytic capacity, which accelerates the rate of accumulation of C1q-coated senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration. These studies provide a mechanistic explanation for the association of APOE4 with AD risk and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for AD.

The Earth's inner core is a solid sphere with a diameter of 2,890 km, which is the largest solid body in the solar system. The inner core is thought to have formed by the solidification of the core material. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still controversial. In this study, we demonstrate that the nucleation of the inner core is likely to be a two-step process. The first step is the nucleation of the bcc phase of iron, which is the stable phase at the inner core temperature. The second step is the nucleation of the hcp phase, which is the stable phase at the outer core temperature. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. Our study also suggests that the inner core is likely to be composed of bcc iron. This study provides a new perspective on the formation of the inner core. It also provides a new perspective on the structure and anisotropy of the inner core.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the drug is widely available, there is a need to understand the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA). Specifically, marijuana abusers show reduced decreases in striatal dopamine and in brain reactivity to methylphenidate. These findings suggest that chronic marijuana use is associated with decreased brain reactivity to DA stimulation, which might contribute to the negative emotionality and addictive behaviors of marijuana abusers.

Language is a uniquely human ability, and the brain’s mechanisms for comprehending it are poorly understood. Here, we use a state-of-the-art machine learning approach to study the brain’s processing of language. We find that the most powerful models of the language data also outperform humans on this task, and that model architecture is strongly correlated with neural fit. These results provide computational evidence that predictive processing fundamentally shapes the brain’s mechanisms for comprehending language. They also suggest that the brain may usefully be viewed as a large statistical model of language, which can be improved by incorporating more data and more predictive structure. This approach may help us understand the brain’s mechanisms for language and other complex cognitive and social skills.

Deep learning (DL) has had unprecedented success in many areas of science and engineering. However, it is still unclear whether the success of DL is due to its ability to approximate any function, or whether it is just a coincidence. In this paper, we show that the latter is the case. We prove that there are problems in scientific computing where one can prove the existence of stable neural networks (NNs) with great approximation qualities; however, there does not exist any algorithm, even randomized, that can train (or compute) such a NN. This implies that the success of DL is not due to its ability to approximate any function, but rather due to the fact that it is a coincidence. Our results have implications for the future of scientific computing.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including a failure to understand exponential growth. This classic experiment from 1972 is often cited as evidence for this phenomenon. However, it is widely known for its methodological flaws. Here, we discuss these in the context of the COVID-19 pandemic and the broader field of social psychology. We argue that the experiment’s flaws should have been recognized and addressed at the time, and that the study should not be considered a “gold standard” of social psychology.

Leprosy is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by Mycobacterium leprae. The disease is characterized by progressive loss of sensation and disfigurement. The disease is curable with multidrug therapy, but the mechanism of disease is not understood. Here we report the genome sequence of a Mexican patient with lepromatous leprosy. The genome sequence reveals that the two leprosy species have retained many of the same functions and have lost similar functions. This suggests that the two species are still capable of causing disease.

Entanglement and thermodynamics are two of the most fundamental concepts in physics. They are also the two pillars of quantum information theory, which is the main field of application of entanglement. The study of the evolution of entanglement is therefore a key step in the understanding of the emergence of thermodynamics in isolated quantum systems. We show that the quasiparticle picture of the entanglement dynamics, complemented with integrability-based knowledge of the steady state and its excitations, leads to a complete understanding of the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain. This work is a step toward the understanding of the entanglement dynamics in generic interacting systems.

COVID-19 is a pandemic that has caused millions of deaths worldwide. The development of a vaccine is the most effective way to control the pandemic. However, the current vaccines are not 100% effective. Therefore, it is necessary to develop a vaccine with a high efficacy. In this study, we developed a vaccine that can induce a strong immune response against the spike protein of SARS-CoV-2. The vaccine is based on a modified version of the SARS virus. The vaccine is easy to manufacture and can be mass produced. The vaccine is also safe and can induce a strong immune response. Therefore, this vaccine has the potential to be used in mass vaccination programs.

Plague is a disease with a long history of human suffering and death. It is caused by the bacterium Yersinia pestis and can spread by multiple transmission pathways. Today, most human plague cases are bubonic, caused by spillover of infected fleas from rodent epizootics, or pneumonic, caused by inhalation of infectious droplets. However, little is known about the historical spread of plague in Europe during the Second Pandemic (14–19th centuries), including the Black Death, which led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. Here, we describe a compartmental model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector. Using Bayesian inference, we found that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for pneumonic or rodent transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study has implications for our understanding of the history of plague and the evolution of vector control. It also has implications for the spread of other diseases by human ectoparasites.

The evolution of brain size has been used as a proxy for the evolution of brain power. However, this approach is biased because brain size is not the only factor that determines the computational capacity of the brain. We use the largest dataset of its kind to reconstruct the evolution of brain size in amniotes. We show that reptiles have not only small brains relative to body size but also low neuronal densities, resulting in average neuron numbers over 20 times lower than those in birds and mammals of similar body size. Amniote brain evolution is characterized by the following four major shifts in neuron–brain scaling. The most dramatic increases in brain neurons occurred independently with the appearance of birds and mammals, resulting in convergent neuron scaling in the two endotherm lineages. The other two major increases happened in core land birds and anthropoid primates, which are two groups known for their cognitive prowess.

The role of TRAP1 in cancer is controversial. Some studies suggest that TRAP1 is a tumor suppressor, whereas others suggest that it is an oncogene. Here, we show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor in some settings.

Actin filaments are the major cytoskeletal elements that mediate cell motility and shape. They are also the targets of the actin depolymerizing factor (ADF)/cofilin family of proteins. ADF/cofilin is a key regulator of the actin cytoskeleton, but how it does so is not well understood. Here, we use single-molecule, single-filament, and filament network techniques to study the action of ADF/cofilin in different mechanical situations. We find that ADF/cofilin binds to actin filaments and severes them in a mechanical-torque-dependent manner. This mechanochemical mechanism is critical to boost ADF/cofilin’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. Our findings provide insights into the mechanism of ADF/cofilin action and may help us understand its role in cell motility and cancer metastasis. This mechanism may also be relevant to other filament severing proteins.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often consumed in excess. This study suggests that fructose may promote feeding behavior. We found that fructose relative to glucose resulted in greater brain activation in response to food cues and greater hunger and desire for food. These findings suggest that fructose may increase the likelihood of overconsuming calories.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean that exhibits a unique combination of cultural, linguistic, and genetic traits from both Southeast Asia and Eastern Africa. We used a grid-based approach to sample at high resolution the genomic diversity across Madagascar. We find a common Bantu and Austronesian descent for all Malagasy individuals. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the settlement happened in a sex-biased and geographically heterogeneous manner. In addition, we show that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. These results provide insights into the settlement history of Madagascar and the origin of the Malagasy people. They also provide a unique dataset for future studies on the human population history of Madagascar. This dataset will be available at http://www.malagasygenomes.org/.

Emotional contagion is the process by which people experience the same emotions as others. It is well established in laboratory experiments, but the extent to which it occurs in the real world is unclear. We test whether emotional contagion occurs outside of in-person interaction between individuals by reducing the amount of emotional content in the News Feed of Facebook users. When positive expressions were reduced, people produced fewer positive posts and more negative posts; when negative expressions were reduced, the opposite pattern occurred. These results indicate that emotions expressed by others on Facebook influence our own emotions, constituting experimental evidence for massive-scale contagion via social networks. This work also suggests that, in contrast to prevailing assumptions, in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. Our results have implications for understanding the spread of emotions in society. They also suggest that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. This work may help to explain the popularity of social media. Finally, our results have implications for the design of social media platforms. For example, reducing the amount of emotional content may help to reduce the spread of negative emotions.

The ribosome is the molecular machine responsible for translating messenger RNA (mRNA) into a protein. The mRNA sequences that direct protein synthesis are not the only sequences that the ribosome encounters. There is a growing appreciation that mRNA sequences can also be posttranscriptionally modified. The enzymatic incorporation of mRNA modifications has many potential outcomes, including changing mRNA stability, protein recruitment, and translation. We show that the presence of one of the most common modifications present in mRNA coding regions, pseudouridine (Ψ), impedes amino acid addition and EF-Tu GTPase activation. We also find that the presence of Ψ can promote the low-level synthesis of multiple peptide products from a single mRNA sequence in the bacterial translation system. These findings suggest that the ribosome encounters Ψ can modestly alter both translation speed and mRNA decoding. This may be a general mechanism for the impact of mRNA modifications on translation.

The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including stronger social relationships, broader social engagement, less loneliness, better mental and physical health, less chronic pain, less disability, healthier lifestyles, and less time spent alone. These associations are robust to a range of sensitivity analyses, and the feeling that life is filled with worthwhile activities may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages. These findings have implications for public health and gerontology.

The evolution of larger body size is a defining characteristic of many lineages of mammals. This study tests the extent to which the aquatic lifestyle is driving the evolution of larger body size in mammals. We find that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. The existence of this body size attractor and the relatively rapid selection toward, and limited deviation from, this attractor rule out most hypothesized drivers of size increase. These results are consistent with control by differences in the scaling of energetic intake and cost functions with body size between the terrestrial and aquatic realms. The aquatic lifestyle is driving and confining mammals to larger body sizes. This study provides a quantitative test of the role of the aquatic lifestyle in driving the evolution of body size in mammals. It also provides a framework for understanding the evolution of body size in other aquatic organisms.

The common cold is the most common viral infection in the world. The virus that causes the vast majority of colds is rhinovirus. The virus replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures of the nasal cavity than at body temperature. We show that the virus exploits this temperature preference to replicate more efficiently in the nasal cavity.

Bacteria use a variety of mechanisms to sense their environment. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its type IV pili to detect surfaces. This mechanism is used to promote long-term attachment to surfaces, which is required for the pathogen to survive and cause infection. We propose a mechanochemical model where the mechanical activity of the pili is sensed by a chemosensory system, which in turn regulates the activity of the pili. This mechanism is likely to be used by other bacteria to detect surfaces and may be important for the survival of many pathogens.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the last decades. However, the impact of pesticides on aquatic ecosystems is still poorly understood. We provide a comprehensive analysis of the global occurrence of pesticides in surface waters. We show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. Our results suggest the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions. This study is a first step toward a better understanding of the impact of pesticides on the global environment.

SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, has spread globally and has been documented in a variety of animal species. However, the role of animals in the transmission of SARS-CoV-2 is unknown. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in white-tailed deer. We show that deer can be infected with SARS-CoV-2 and can transmit the virus to other deer. Our findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic.

The world is moving toward a low-carbon energy future. This paper examines the proliferation of large dams in developing countries and the importance of incorporating climate change into considerations of whether to build a dam. We also examine the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable energy sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the lack of effective treatments has led to a global health crisis. The disease is believed to be caused by the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) and tau protein in the brain, but the mechanisms underlying this accumulation are not fully understood. Here, we show that soluble Aβ is toxic to neurons, and that the accumulation of Aβ in the brain is not necessary for the production of inflammatory factors by neurons. We demonstrate that the accumulation of Aβ in neurons is sufficient to trigger the production of inflammatory factors, which may contribute to the development of AD. Our results provide a new perspective on the pathogenesis of AD, and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies.

The domestication of chickens (Gallus gallus domesticus) is traditionally dated to the second millennium B.C.E. in the Near East. However, the earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens is still missing. Here we present the results of a faunal analysis of 234 sites in the Southern Levant, spanning more than three millennia. Our results show that the frequency of chicken bones increases sharply in the Hellenistic period, which is the earliest period in which we can securely identify economic exploitation of chickens. We argue that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later.

The folding of a protein is a complex process that is not yet understood. We have developed a method that allows the study of the folding of a large protein at high structural resolution. We have used this method to study the folding of maltose binding protein, a protein that has been studied extensively. We find that the folding of maltose binding protein is a multistep process.

Dinucleoside tetraphosphates are alarmones that accumulate in response to stress. In bacteria, they function as precursors to RNA caps that are required for rapid degradation of the capped transcripts. In Escherichia coli, the predominant decapping enzyme, ApaH, is inactivated by the very conditions of disulfide stress that enable accumulation of alarmones. Here, we show that the RNA pyrophosphohydrolase RppH, which is not known to decaptate RNA, becomes the major enzyme responsible for decapping alarmones in the presence of stress. We show that RppH decapsulates alarmones by a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to decaptulate other RNAs. This enzyme recognizes the 5′ ends of alarmones by a mechanism that generates a one-nucleotide shift in the 5′ terminus of the decapped RNA. This shift is required for the second deprotection step required for rapid degradation of the capped RNA.

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and poor clinical outcome. The mechanisms involved in the immune dysfunction during sepsis are not fully understood. We hypothesized that increasing arginine availability would restore T cell function and decrease immunosuppression. We demonstrated that citrulline administration was more efficient than arginine in increasing arginine plasma levels and restoring T cell mitochondrial function and proliferation while reducing immunosuppression. Because there is no specific therapeutic strategy to restore immune function after sepsis, we believe that our study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. This study may also have implications for other conditions in which immune dysfunction is associated with poor clinical outcome. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The biomass of the biosphere is a fundamental quantity that is essential for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined. We also highlight the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass of the biosphere and its distribution among the kingdoms of life. This information is essential for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. This work is a step toward a global census of the biosphere.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in nature and in physics that is characterized by the absence of an external driving force and the presence of long-range correlations. SOC systems are characterized by a power-law distribution of activity, which is a signature of criticality. In this paper, we report on the discovery of a continuous SOC system. Our model is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is widely used in many applications, but its properties can be improved. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly under mechanical strain. We also show that diamond can be used as a high-performance mechanical strain sensor. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. The findings are expected to be useful for the development of new applications of diamond.

The role of plant immune peptides in defense against fungal pathogens is well established. However, the structural basis for their antifungal activity is not known. Here, we report the structure of a 36-residue NCR peptide from Medicago truncatula, which is a member of a large family of nodule-specific peptides. The structure of this peptide is largely disordered and dynamic. It exhibits potent antifungal activity against multiple plant fungal pathogens. It binds to multiple bioactive phosphoinositides in vitro and induces reactive oxygen species in germlings of the fungal pathogen Botrytis cinerea. This work illustrates the structural basis for antifungal activity of a unique NCR peptide and paves the way for future development of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes. In the case of internally fertilizing species, such as insects, the male’s contribution to the female’s offspring is likely to be limited to the sperm. However, the extent of such contributions is largely unknown. Here, we show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm undergoes substantial changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that the female reproductive tract contributes to the sperm proteome, and that these contributions support sperm viability during the prolonged period between copulation and fertilization. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the sperm proteome and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. This work will be of interest to the broader proteomics community and will be useful for understanding the molecular basis of sperm–FRT interactions in other species. (Show more)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, promoting blood clotting. Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that force application switches VWF to a second state with faster binding, providing a mechanism for the observed gain of function. This mechanism explains the effects of mutations in VWD. The force-dependent switching is a mechanism for regulating protein function.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem that has been the focus of intense study for the past decade. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been more difficult to study, in part because of the lack of a comprehensive database. We have created a database, Microbiome-Scale Virus Taxonomy (MicroViT), that provides a comprehensive view of the human virome. We use this database to identify previously unknown associations between viruses and disease. We also show that the human virome is more complex than previously thought.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a key process in the climate system. However, the ACI is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the complexity of the ACI process and the lack of observational capability. Here, we introduce a new instrument, the dual-FOV high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to investigate the ACI. The HSRL can simultaneously measure aerosol and cloud properties, especially cloud microphysical properties. We demonstrate the capability of the HSRL to investigate the ACI. The results show that the HSRL can provide significant contributions to the ACI investigations. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. It is expected to be a significant contributor to the ACI investigations. This instrument will be a significant contribution to the global climate change research.

The temperature of the early Earth has been a topic of intense debate. The temperature of the surface of the early Earth is important for understanding the origin of life. We used the thermostability of reconstructed ancestral enzymes to infer the temperature of the surface of the early Earth. Our results suggest that the temperature of the surface of the early Earth decreased over geological time from ∼65–80 °C in the Archean, a finding consistent both with previous isotope-based and protein reconstruction-based interpretations. Interdisciplinary studies such as those reported here integrating genomic, geologic, and paleontologic data hold promise for providing new insight into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history. Ion channels are the main ion conduits in cells and are regulated by two types of gates: activation/deactivation gates and inactivation gates. The large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel lacks a classic activation gate and normally shows no C-type inactivation. We found that the BK channel’s C-type inactivation is closed state-dependent and that its extents and rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability. Because C-type inactivation can involve multiple conformational changes at the selectivity filter, we propose that the BK channel’s closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. Our findings may help us understand the BK channel’s unique properties and may provide a new approach for drug development. This study also provides a new paradigm for the regulation of ion channels.

Malaria is a major cause of death worldwide, with 435,000 deaths occurring in 2016. The parasite exploits the host cell to facilitate invasion, a process that has been the subject of intense study for decades. Here, we show that the malaria parasite alters the biophysical properties of the host erythrocyte, reducing a critical energy barrier to invasion. This finding would suggest that invasion is a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces working together to facilitate entry. This is a major change in our understanding of the invasion process and could lead to the development of new strategies to combat the disease. This work has implications for the development of new malaria vaccines and therapeutics. (Show more)

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is widely used in many applications, such as in cutting tools, jewelry, and sensors. However, it is brittle and has a low fracture toughness. In this work, we show that diamond can be metallized, which is a unique property of metals, without phonon instability. This opens up new possibilities for diamond applications.

Influenza virus is a major cause of respiratory disease in humans and animals. In the temperate regions, seasonal outbreaks of influenza virus correlate with decreases in humidity. While low ambient humidity is known to enhance viral transmission, its impact on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes mice more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that inhalation of dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low relative humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. Single-cell RNA sequencing revealed that induction of IFN-stimulated genes in response to viral infection was diminished in multiple cell types in the lung of mice housed in low humidity condition. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our study provides insights into the impact of dry air on host defense and disease outcome, which may be relevant to the control of influenza virus infection in the field. The brain is thought to build a tree-like structure of syntactic relations between words as it processes a sentence. This structure is thought to be important for understanding the meaning of the sentence. We used intracranial recordings to investigate how the brain builds this structure. We found that the brain builds a phrase structure for each word in a sentence, and that the brain uses the same merge operation to combine words into phrases. Our results suggest that the brain uses a bottom-up parser to build a phrase structure for each word in a sentence. This parser is similar to the left-corner parser proposed by linguists.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major signaling pathway in vertebrates that regulates many aspects of development. The pathway is regulated by two scaffolds, Axin1 and Axin2. We show that the two scaffolds are regulated differently in different tissues.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region of the brain that regulates feeding. Electrical stimulation of LH neurons causes vigorous eating in sated animals. We show that this effect is mediated by a circuit involving dopamine neurons in the ventral tegmental area (VTA) and the LH. We also show that this circuit is not involved in the regulation of hunger or satiety. Thus, we present a characterization of brain circuitry that may promote overeating and contribute to obesity.

Nitrogen is the most important nutrient for plant growth, and the availability of nitrogen is the primary factor limiting crop yields. The ability to control the nitrogen-fixing bacteria in the plant root environment would allow for the delivery of nitrogen to the plant only when needed, thus improving nitrogen use efficiency and crop yields. Here, we have developed a system that allows for the control of nitrogen fixation in barley plants by the bacteria that colonize their roots. This system represents a key step toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work is a significant step toward the development of a sustainable nitrogen-fixing symbiosis in agriculture. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The Amazon is the world’s most important tropical forest and is under increasing pressure from deforestation. Remote-sensed deforestation alerts are widely used to monitor and mitigate this pressure. However, the effectiveness of these systems in reducing deforestation is unknown. We study a community-based monitoring program that uses remote-sensed alerts to train and incentivize community members to patrol forests in response to alerts. We find that the program reduced deforestation in the communities that participated. However, the estimated effects are imprecise because of the program’s small sample size. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals use their hearing to perceive the world around them. The auditory organs of animals are diverse in anatomy after hundreds of millions of years of evolution, yet all are made up of cellular tissue and are morphologically part of the body of the animal. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is extended through outsourcing hearing to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web. We find that the spider’s web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna to sense the motion of web threads, which allows the spider to remotely detect and localize the source of an incoming airborne acoustic wave. By outsourcing its acoustic sensors to its web, the spider is released from body size constraints and permits the araneid spider to increase its sound-sensitive surface area enormously, up to 10,000 times greater than the spider itself. The outsourcing and supersizing of auditory function in spiders provide unique features for studying extended and regenerative sensing and designing novel acoustic flow detectors for precise fluid dynamic measurement and manipulation. Climate change and air pollution are two of the most pressing global health issues. We estimate the climate and health benefits of a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources. We find that a phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources can save 3.61 (2.96–4.21) million lives per year from outdoor air pollution and 5.55 (4.52–6.52) million lives per year from all anthropogenic sources. This would also reduce the global temperature by 0.51(±0.03) °C and the excess mortality from aerosols by 0.73(±0.03) °C. The health benefits are even larger if we additionally control nonfossil anthropogenic sources. Our results highlight the importance of reducing greenhouse gas emissions and air pollution simultaneously. This will not only save millions of lives but also limit global warming to 2 °C.

COVID-19 is a global pandemic with over 200 million cases and over 4.2 million deaths worldwide. The need for a global vaccine supply is urgent. We report the design and synthesis of a SARS-CoV-2 RBD protein that is well-suited for large-scale production. This protein is highly immunogenic and can be used to generate a virus-like particle (VLP) vaccine. This VLP can be produced in large quantities using a robust, scalable, and cost-effective microbial platform. The VLP can be produced in a single step, without the need for purification steps, and can be formulated with adjuvants to enhance immunogenicity. This VLP can be used to develop vaccines for COVID-19 and other coronaviruses.

The ALK family of receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) is involved in a variety of human cancers. In the zebrafish, the DrALK/DrLtk signaling pathway is involved in the development of iridophores, pigment cells of neural crest origin. Here, we show that the DrALK/DrLtk signaling pathway is also involved in the development of neural crest-derived tissues in the Drosophila eye. Our results provide in vivo evidence of (i) activation of ALK/LTK family receptors by ALKALs and (ii) an involvement of these ligand–receptor complexes in neural crest development. These findings may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for neuroblastoma and other ALK-driven cancers. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Plague has been a scourge of humanity for millennia, and the emergence of Yersinia pestis from its progenitor Yersinia pseudotuberculosis is one of the most dramatic events in the history of infectious disease. The timing of this event is still debated, and the available evidence is limited to a few genomes recovered from the Neolithic period. Here, we present 17 Y. pestis genomes recovered from the Bronze Age to provide a more complete picture of the pathogen’s evolution and ecology during this critical period. Our results reveal a nonflea-adapted and potentially extinct lineage that persisted over millennia without significant parallel diversification, accompanied by rapid dispersal across continents. These data provide insights into the early evolution and ecology of plague, and the presence of the flea-adapted form of the pathogen in Iberia suggests a much wider geographic spread of this form of plague. This study also highlights the importance of ancient DNA in the study of the origins of devastating diseases. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

This work examined the relationship between men’s and women’s endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity (hegemonic masculinity) and their support for Donald Trump. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, in the days (Studies 1 and 2) and months (Studies 3 through 6) following the 2016 American presidential election, women’s and men’s endorsement of hegemonic masculinity predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. In addition, as conceptualized, hegemonic masculinity predicted less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of hegemonic masculinity legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. The findings have implications for understanding the political climate in the United States. (PsycINFO

Soil organic carbon (SOC) sequestration is a critical strategy for mitigating climate change. However, the management of annual cropping systems on grasslands is a major source of SOC loss. We show that soil health management practices that reduce soil disturbance, diversify crop rotations, and integrate livestock can increase SOC storage and the amount of SOC stored in the mineral soil. These results highlight the potential of grasslands to sequester SOC and provide a framework for designing climate-smart agricultural systems. This article is protected by copyright. The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need to identify and characterize viruses that pose the greatest risk of spillover and spread in humans. We used expert opinion and scientific evidence to identify host, viral, and environmental risk factors contributing to zoonotic virus spillover and spread in humans. We then developed a risk ranking framework and interactive web tool, SpillOver, that estimates a risk score for wildlife-origin viruses, creating a comparative risk assessment of viruses with uncharacterized zoonotic spillover potential alongside those already known to be zoonotic. We validated the risk assessment using data from virus discovery projects and public records of virus detections around the world. The SpillOver platform can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. This work provides a roadmap for the systematic identification and prioritization of viruses with the greatest potential to spillover and spread in humans.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for pollination services. The color of nectar is often used as an indicator of the reward’s nutritional value. Here, we show that the color of the red nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid. We identify the three enzymatic activities that are necessary for the production of this pigment. We also identify the alkaloid in the red nectar of two distantly related species, which have evolved this trait convergently. This work suggests that the red nectar of Nesocodon and Jaltomata is selectively favored and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work provides insight into the evolution of a unique floral trait.

The genetic history of Europe during the Early Middle Ages is poorly understood. Here we present the genome of 11 individuals from Bavaria, Germany, dating to the 6th century AD. We find that the genetic ancestry of men is mostly consistent with modern northern and central Europeans, but that women exhibit a very high genetic heterogeneity. This heterogeneity includes signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. In addition, we show that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. These results indicate that complex demographic processes during the Early Middle Ages may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape. Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how HKU4 and HKU5 transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. In humans, pol δ is responsible for replicating the Okazaki fragments of the lagging strand template during replication of the nucleus. The origin of life is one of the most important and enigmatic problems in biology. The RNA world is a hypothesized stage in the evolution of life, in which genetic information was encoded by RNA molecules and replicated by ribozymes. In the RNA world, proteins were not yet needed, and the origin of proteins is a major unsolved problem. Here, we report the successful reconstruction of the RNA world in vitro. We used in vitro evolution to improve the activity of an RNA polymerase ribozyme, which can synthesize RNA from an RNA template. The improved polymerase can now replicate RNA, amplify RNA by PCR, and synthesize a variety of functional RNA molecules. These results provide a foundation for the study of the origin of life in the laboratory. They also provide a model for the evolution of RNA-based life from a state in which proteins were not yet needed.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also suggest that the physical appearance of neighborhoods may be a useful indicator of the economic and demographic characteristics of the residents who live there. This may have implications for urban planning and policy.

COVID-19 is a new type of pneumonia, which has caused a large number of deaths worldwide. The pathogenesis of COVID-19 is still unclear. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which targets the IL-6 pathway, can improve the clinical outcome of severe and critical COVID-19 patients. Therefore, tocilizumab may be a potential treatment for COVID-19.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but also a toxic metal that can cause oxidative damage. The fungal genus Aspergillus is a model organism for studying the mechanisms of copper homeostasis. The xanthocillin biosynthetic gene cluster (BGC) was recently identified in Aspergillus fumigatus, but the function of the BGC in copper homeostasis was unknown. Here we demonstrate that the xan BGC is involved in copper homeostasis and that the BGC products are antimicrobial. The existence of the xan BGC in several filamentous fungi suggests a heretofore unknown role of eukaryotic natural products in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. This study provides insight into the role of fungal natural products in the regulation of copper homeostasis and the interactions of fungi with other microbes. This knowledge may be useful in the development of antifungal agents. (Show more)

Tridymite is a low-pressure, high-temperature (>870 °C) polymorph of SiO2 that is commonly associated with silicic volcanism. The detection of tridymite in a sedimentary rock at Gale crater, Mars, is significant because it is a rare SiO2 polymorph in the solar system. The tridymite is cogenetic with other crystalline minerals and possibly the amorphous silica, and is possibly derived from silicic volcanism in the vicinity of the sedimentary rock source. The amorphous silica is cogenetic with the crystalline minerals and possibly derived from multiple aqueous solutions with variable compositions, temperatures, and acidities. The post-lithification fracture/vein fill anhydrite is possibly derived from a different aqueous solution.

Frost damage is a major threat to plant productivity and a major cause of economic losses in agriculture and forestry. The geographic distribution of frost events is poorly understood, and the evolutionary impact of frost on plants is also poorly known. We show that the geographic distribution of frost events is strongly associated with the evolutionary strategies of trees. We also show that the frequency of frost events is increasing in some regions, and that this increase will likely lead to increasing frost damage in the future. Our findings can help decision-makers to adapt to the changing frost risk.

Th17 cells are central to the pathogenesis of certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the developmental pathways that give rise to Th17 cells are not well understood. We found that Th17 cells were unable to induce colitis in recipients of a Th17 transfer, indicating that they require the development of a subset of Th17 cells to induce disease. These cells were dependent on the expression of the transcription factor T-bet, but not the IL-12 or IFN-γ receptors. Moreover, Th17 cells could provide “help” for the development of classic Th1 cells. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis by dual mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. Understanding the mechanisms that give rise to these subsets will improve our understanding of the pathogenesis of inflammatory bowel disease. (Show more)

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, leading to paralysis and death. The disease is heterogeneous, with different genetic causes and different clinical courses. There is a need for disease modeling to understand the disease mechanisms and develop therapeutics. We report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living patients with ALS. This will enable high-throughput drug screening to identify potential therapies. This method will also enable disease modeling to understand the disease mechanisms and identify potential therapies.

The gut microbiota of arthropod vectors plays a critical role in pathogen colonization and development. Here, we show that the tick-borne pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum modifies the gut microbiota to facilitate infection. We demonstrate that the pathogen induces the expression of antifreeze glycoprotein (iafgp), which alters the composition of the gut microbiota and perturbs the integrity of the peritrophic matrix and gut barrier. These data reveal a mechanism by which a pathogen modifies the gut microbiota to facilitate infection. This study provides insight into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the gut microbiota of arthropod vectors. This knowledge may lead to the development of strategies to control vector-borne diseases. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in vertebrate evolution. The short-tailed bird group Pygostylia is a major evolutionary lineage that includes the origin of the modern avian bauplan. However, the currently limited known diversity of early branching members of Pygostylia obscures our understanding of this major transition in avian evolution. Here, we describe a basal member of Pygostylia, Jinguofortis perplexus, from the Early Cretaceous of China. This new taxon adds important information about the early evolution of the short-tailed bird group.

We show that the stratosphere is a major contributor to the climate system. This is because the stratosphere is the region where the temperature of the atmosphere increases with height. This is in contrast to the troposphere, where the temperature decreases with height. We show that the stratosphere is also a major source of water vapor to the troposphere.

Vertebrates have evolved a variety of colors, from red to blue, to camouflage themselves from predators and prey. In some species, the color of the animal is determined by the presence of specific proteins that bind to specific molecules in the environment. In this study, we describe a new mechanism of color control in frogs, which is based on the presence of a protein that binds biliverdin, a molecule that is normally present in the blood. This mechanism is most similar to the color control mechanisms in plants, and it provides a new mechanism of color control in vertebrates.

Hypoxia is a feature of many cancers, and hypoxia-inducible factors (HIFs) are key regulators of the tumor microenvironment. Here, we show that HIF-dependent expression of ALKBH5, an m6A demethylase, regulates the expression of NANOG, a key factor in the maintenance of pluripotency. We show that ALKBH5 overexpression increases the percentage of breast cancer stem cells, and that ALKBH5 knockdown decreases the percentage of breast cancer stem cells. Thus, ALKBH5 may be a therapeutic target for cancer treatment.

Parchment is the most common material used for the production of books. It is made from animal skin, and the source of this material has been a long-standing controversy. The Latin term abortivum in many sources has led some scholars to suggest that fetal calves or sheep were used. Others have argued that it would not be possible to sustain herds if so many pocket Bibles were produced from fetal skins, arguing instead for unexpected alternatives, such as rabbit. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. The noninvasive method is a variant on zooarchaeology by mass spectrometry (ZooMS) peptide mass fingerprinting but extracts protein from the parchment surface by using an electrostatic charge generated by gentle rubbing of a PVC eraser on the membrane surface. Using this method, we analyzed 72 pocket Bibles originating in France, England, and Italy and 293 additional parchment samples that bracket this period. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe extinction event in the last 542 My. The age model for this event is critical for understanding the causes and mechanisms of extinction and recovery. We present a precise age model for the Permian-Triassic boundary based on U-Pb dates from five volcanic ash beds. The age of the extinction is 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. The carbon cycle reorganization that occurred immediately before the extinction is punctuated by a sharp (3‰) negative spike in the isotopic composition of carbonate carbon. The carbon cycle volatility persists for ∼500 ka before a return to near preextinction values. The timing of the extinction and its aftermath will allow a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction, allowing insight into postextinction ecosystem expansion. This age model will also be critical for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms.

Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a transcription factor that is involved in various biological processes, including circadian rhythm, cancer, and metabolism. Here, we generate intestinal epithelial cell (IEC)-specific RORα-deficient (RORαΔIEC) mice and find that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. RORαΔIEC mice exhibit excessive intestinal inflammation and highly activated inflammatory responses in the dextran sulfate sodium (DSS) mouse colitis model. Transcriptome analysis reveals that deletion of RORα leads to up-regulation of NF-κB target genes in IECs. Chromatin immunoprecipitation analysis reveals corecruitment of RORα and histone deacetylase 3 (HDAC3) on NF-κB target promoters and subsequent dismissal of CREB binding protein (CBP) and bromodomain-containing protein 4 (BRD4) for transcriptional repression. The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for neutralizing antibodies and vaccines. We have used cryo-electron microscopy to determine the structure of the spike protein in complex with the receptor ACE2. We show that the D614G mutation in the spike protein has resulted in a more open conformation of the spike protein. This may facilitate binding to the receptor and the subsequent structural rearrangements required for viral membrane fusion. This may explain the increased infectivity of the mutant virus.

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs. Our results extend to a large class of games with tail-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate the impact of the pandemic on life expectancy at birth and at age 65 y for the total US population and by race and ethnicity. Our projections indicate that the pandemic will result in a substantial decline in life expectancy at birth and at age 65 y for Black and Latino Americans, and that the gap in life expectancy between Black and White Americans will increase. These findings have important implications for health policy and for the future of the US population.

The chemical properties of an atom are the basis of all chemistry. The chemical potential of an electron is the driving force of chemical reactions. In this work, we calculate the chemical potential of an electron in a given atom under pressure. We find that the chemical potential of an electron decreases with pressure, and that the elements become more metallic. We also discover that the pseudo–noble-gas elements Ni, Pd, and Pt are electron donors, while the pseudo–metal elements Fe, Co, Rh, and Ir are electron acceptors. This work provides a new perspective on the chemical properties of the elements and their behavior under pressure. It also has the potential to be used as a predictive tool for the behavior of the elements under pressure.

Climate change is expected to increase fire activity in many regions, but the impact on the global carbon cycle is poorly understood. We show that changes in human demography can reduce fire activity, which in turn reduces warming. This effect is most pronounced under lower emissions scenarios. Our results highlight the importance of fire in the climate system and the need to better understand the feedbacks between climate, fire, and carbon.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their tissues. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the provision of a single glycan to its luminescent symbiont, Vibrio fischeri, in a diel rhythm. This glycan is catabolized by the symbiont, which is thus able to maintain a healthy population level only after the organ has matured. This glycan is also required for the acidification of the crypts, which enhances the luminescence of the symbiont. We propose that this strategy is used by other hosts to regulate the activities of their associated microbes. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Text data are ubiquitous, and the need to identify latent patterns in them is growing. We introduce a method to identify topics in a corpus and represent documents as topic sequences. We draw on advances in theoretical machine learning to integrate topic modeling and word embedding, capitalizing on their distinct capabilities. Our method can identify the gender bias of topics and their prevalence in narratives of female versus male victims. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. It can be applied to many domains and is likely to be useful in many applications.

The second plague pandemic, which started with the arrival of the Black Death in Europe in the 14th century, lasted for four centuries. This event is generally understood as the consequence of a single introduction of Yersinia pestis, after which the disease established itself in European rodents over four centuries. Here, we provide evidence for repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our analysis finds no support for the existence of permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe. Instead, we suggest that the Black Death was the result of multiple introductions of the disease, which were delayed by 15 ± 1 y by climate-driven changes in the rodent population. This study provides evidence for a more complex picture of the spread of the plague, which is important for understanding the history of the disease and its impact on human societies.
