Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web and are important for the functioning of coastal ecosystems. However, they are also a food source for a number of predators, including sea stars. In the Northeast Pacific, asteroids have recently experienced an extensive outbreak of wasting disease. We show that the disease is caused by a densovirus. This is the first report of a densovirus associated with a disease outbreak in asteroids.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia in adults. Despite advances in therapy, the prognosis of AML remains poor, and there is an urgent need for novel and more efficient therapies. We show here that monoclonal antibodies targeting the IL1RAP (IL1R3) receptor can efficiently target AML stem cells in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. Because IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of AML cells, we generated an IL1RAP-targeting antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an anti-IL1RAP antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. Collectively, these results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This study provides a proof-of-concept for the use of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This approach may be applicable

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean that exhibits a unique combination of cultural, linguistic, and genetic traits. We used a grid-based approach to sample genomic diversity across Madagascar. We find that Madagascar is a mosaic of African and Asian ancestry. The settlement history of Madagascar is also unique. We find that Madagascar was settled by a population that was already admixed. However, the settlement history of Madagascar is not homogeneous, suggesting that the settlement of Madagascar happened independently from Africa and Asia. In addition, we find that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a unique view of the settlement history of Madagascar. It also provides a unique view of the genetic diversity of Madagascar. This study will help us understand the settlement history of Madagascar and the diversity of Madagascar.

Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). We discovered the membrane-associated AzuC protein interacts with GlpD, the aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, and increases dehydrogenase activity. Overexpression of the RNA encoding AzuC results in a growth defect in glycerol and galactose medium. The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work may help to accelerate the development of next-generation vaccines and therapeutics.

Crop experts are the primary source of information on crop status in many countries. However, their data are often not used in agricultural decision-making because of the perceived subjectivity of the information. We show that the data of crop experts can be transformed into a continuous, probabilistic variable that is statistically robust and has nation-wide validity. We demonstrate that this index can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official forecasts released midseason. Our results show that the crop expert network is a valuable source of information that can be used to improve agricultural decision-making. This approach can be used to monitor crop status and provide early warnings of crop anomalies, which can be used to mitigate the impact of natural disasters and improve agricultural production.

Language is a complex system that requires the integration of information over time. The brain is thought to accomplish this through the maintenance of information in the form of elevated neural activity. Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on the adaptive modulation of neuronal excitability. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can bind information over time. We show that this mechanism can support the binding of linguistic features within a sequence of words. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, yet its response to climate change remains uncertain. In this study, we synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. The transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy is one of the most important evolutionary events in the history of life. It is also one of the most studied, but the molecular mechanisms underlying this transition remain poorly understood. Here, we present a model of the trajectory of plastid genome evolution during the transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle. We show that the transition from autotrophy to parasitism is accompanied by a stepwise relaxation of functional constraints on the plastid genome. Our findings have implications for the evolution of plastid genomes in general and for the evolution of the photosynthetic apparatus in particular. They also provide a framework for the study of the molecular evolution of the plastid genome in the context of the evolution of the host.

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark reminder of the vulnerability of cities to climate change. We use a high-resolution climate model to estimate the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear rainfall deficits in southwestern South Africa. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. Our findings are important for informing adaptation strategies and for raising awareness of the climate change dimension of the current drought. This article is protected by copyright. The first nuclear test explosion, the Trinity test of 16 July 1945, released more energy in 1 minute than all the world’s bombs combined at the time. The test resulted in the fusion of surrounding sand, the test tower, and copper transmission lines into a glassy material known as “trinitite.” Here, we report the discovery, in a sample of red trinitite, of a hitherto unknown composition of icosahedral quasicrystal, Si61Cu30Ca7Fe2. It represents the oldest extant anthropogenic quasicrystal currently known, with the distinctive property that its precise time of creation is indelibly etched in history. Like the naturally formed quasicrystals found in the Khatyrka meteorite and experimental shock syntheses of quasicrystals, the anthropogenic quasicrystals in red trinitite demonstrate that transient extreme pressure–temperature conditions are suitable for the synthesis of quasicrystals and for the discovery of new quasicrystal-forming systems. (Bacterio)chlorophyll biosynthesis is one of the most productive biological pathways on Earth. Photosynthesis relies on these modified tetrapyrroles for the capture of solar radiation and its conversion to chemical energy. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the key reaction in the biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophylls, has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated enzymes using different chemistries. The majority of anoxygenic phototrophic bacteria use a [4Fe-4S] cluster protein, BchE, whereas plants, cyanobacteria, and some phototrophic bacteria possess a diiron protein, AcsF. Plant and cyanobacterial mutants in ycf54 display impaired function of the diiron enzyme, accumulating the reaction substrate. Swapping cyclases between cyanobacteria and purple phototrophic bacteria reveals three classes of the diiron enzyme. AcsF is the cyclase in Rubrivivax (Rvi.) gelatinosus, whereas alphaproteobacterial cyclases require a protein encoded by a gene conserved in these organisms. These data delineate three classes of diiron cyclase in chlorophototrophic organisms from higher plants

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in many neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). Neuroinflammation is a complex process that involves multiple cell types, including microglia, astrocytes, and neurons. Neuroinflammation is associated with the activation of mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase (MAP3K) ASK1. In this study, we found that ASK1 in microglia plays a major role in generating and maintaining disease. ASK1-deficient microglia exhibited reduced activation and reduced production of proinflammatory mediators, including CCL2, which further activated and recruited astrocytes. Astrocyte-specific ASK1 deletion was achieved using a CX3CR1CreER system, and we found that ASK1 signaling in microglia played a major role in generating and maintaining disease. Our findings suggest that ASK1 in microglia is a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study provides insights into the role of ASK1 in the glial cell–microglia interaction in EAE. These findings may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for neurodegenerative diseases. (PsycINFO Database Record

The 2012–2014 drought in California was the most extreme in the state’s recorded history. We show that the probability of drought has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is largely attributable to human activities. Our results have important implications for water management and climate change adaptation in California and elsewhere.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability and a complicated etiology. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk gene homologs all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, rather, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. Our study provides a mechanistic understanding of the behavioral inflexibility in autism and suggests a potential therapeutic target. Our findings may also provide insights into the mechanisms of other complex disorders with behavioral inflexibility as a core feature. This study may also help to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms.

This work is the first to report cross-national evidence of negativity biases in news content. It also offers the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. The results suggest that the prevalence of negative news content may be due in part to the fact that people are more likely to react strongly to negative than positive information. The results also suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The CRAC channel is a key component of store-operated Ca2+ entry (SOCE) and is involved in a variety of physiological processes. In this study, we identify mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and the pore-forming protein ORAI1 that lead to constitutive activation of the CRAC channel and to a range of clinical conditions. These data expand our understanding of the molecular function of the CRAC channel and suggest new therapies for patients with Stormorken syndrome and related conditions. The spread of protein aggregates is a key feature of several major neurodegenerative diseases. However, the mechanisms underlying this spreading are poorly understood. Here we use a fluorescently tagged polyglutamine-expanded form of human huntingtin to monitor the spread of aggregates in a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease. We show that aggregates accumulate at synaptic terminals and progressively spread throughout the brain. These aggregates are internalized and accumulate within other neurons. We demonstrate that the release of aggregates requires active endocytosis in the source neuron. These results provide a model for the spread of aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. This article is protected by copyright. However, our understanding of the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats is very limited. Cancer is a disease of rapid cell growth, and one-carbon metabolism is essential for this process. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of the one-carbon metabolism enzymes serine hydroxymethyltransferase 1 and 2 (SHMT1/2). We show that this inhibitor blocks cancer cell growth, and that this effect is dependent on the one-carbon metabolism. We also show that this inhibitor is particularly effective against B-cell cancers, and that this effect is rooted in defective glycine import. Thus, we have identified a metabolic vulnerability of B-cell cancers that can be exploited for cancer therapy. This work provides a foundation for the development of a new class of cancer therapeutics.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous neurodegenerative disease with a high degree of genetic heterogeneity. The disease is characterized by the formation of intracellular inclusion bodies that contain a variety of proteins that do not share obvious characteristics other than coaggregation. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in the brain and spinal cord are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. To explain the presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusions in ALS, we observe that they have an average supersaturation even greater than the average supersaturation of the native interaction partners in motor neurons, but not when scores are generated from an average of other human tissues. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This study provides a new perspective on the pathogenesis of ALS and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (PsycINFO Database Record

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. The earliest known angiosperms are aquatic plants. The study of Montsechia, a plant from the early Cretaceous, raises questions about the very early evolution of this group. The study of Montsechia also raises questions about the role of aquatic habitats in the early evolution of angiosperms.

Parvoviruses are small, nonenveloped DNA viruses that cause a number of diseases in humans. The evolution of parvoviruses has been studied using genetic sequences from living species, but the evolution of the most recent common ancestor of all parvoviruses is unknown. Here we present 10 ancient parvovirus genomes from dental and skeletal remains of individuals who lived in Eurasia and Greenland from ∼0.5 to ∼6.9 thousand years ago. We find that the most recent common ancestor of all parvoviruses is ∼12.6 thousand years old, and we are able to date the recombination event that formed the second genotype to ∼5.0–6.8 thousand years ago. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Show more)

Sea level is a sensitive indicator of climate change. In this study, we provide a new estimate of the rate of sea level rise over the last 25 y. We find that the rate of sea level rise is accelerating, and that this acceleration is consistent with climate change. This finding is important because it provides a more precise estimate of the rate of sea level rise that can be used to inform climate policy.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that pain has increased with age in America, but that this increase has been steeper for those born after 1950 than for those born before 1950. This pattern is seen across multiple measures of pain, including self-report, medical records, and the presence of disability. It is also seen across multiple measures of health, including education, occupation, and obesity. The erosion of working-class life in America is reflected in the erosion of working-class health.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. The application of NMR-assisted crystallography to the study of the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate provides a chemically detailed, three-dimensional picture of the reaction pathway. This detailed picture of the reaction pathway is key to understanding the mechanism of the enzyme.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe and often fatal disease caused by a coronavirus. There is no specific treatment or vaccine for MERS. Here, we show that the broad-spectrum antiviral remdesivir (GS-5734) is effective in a nonhuman primate model of MERS-CoV infection. Remdesivir treatment initiated early after infection provides a clear clinical benefit, with a reduction in clinical signs, reduced virus replication in the lungs, and decreased presence and severity of lung lesions. The data presented here support testing of the efficacy of remdesivir treatment in the context of a MERS clinical trial. It may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This would be of great importance, as there are no approved antiviral treatments for this virus. The development of effective antiviral treatments is therefore of great urgency. The data presented here provide a basis for the development of such treatments. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their tissues. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the provision of a single glycan to its luminescent symbiont, Vibrio fischeri, in a diel rhythm. This glycan is catabolized by the symbiont, which is thus able to maintain a healthy population level only until the organ reaches maturity. This glycan is also required for the acidification of the organ, which enhances the luminescence of the symbiont. We propose that this strategy is used by other hosts to regulate the activities of their associated microbes. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Suspension rates in US schools have increased by 500% since 2000. This study shows that teachers can be encouraged to adopt an empathic rather than punitive mindset about discipline. This change in mindset is associated with a 50% reduction in suspensions. The intervention is scalable and can be implemented in schools across the country.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA lesions that can interfere with the function of DNA. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. We found that the transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis of O2-EtdT and N3-EtdT lesions are exacerbated by TFIIS-stimulated proofreading activity. We also identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop). The Pro-Gate loop faces toward the minor groove of RNA:DNA hybrid and is involved in modulating the translocation of minor-groove alkylated DNA template after nucleotide incorporation opposite the lesion. These findings provide important mechanistic insights into transcriptional stalling, lesion bypass, and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions. The results from the present in vitro transcriptional studies are well correlated with in vivo transcriptional mutagenesis analysis. Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe respiratory disease. Virions require spike (S) glycoproteins for binding to cell receptors and for catalyzing virus–cell membrane fusion. Virions must first be cleaved sequentially by cell-surface proteases, first during their secretion through the exocytic organelles of virus-producing cells, and second after virus binding to target-cell receptors. We found that the first cleavages are significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence. Without the first cleavages, MERS viruses resisted receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. These findings suggest that the first cleavages expand virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection, and therefore may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence. Understanding the determinants of MERS-CoV virulence may lead to the development of more effective countermeasures. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The food system is a major contributor to global warming and other environmental degradation. The food choices people make are a key driver of this problem. In this study, we show that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a large university cafeteria increased the proportion of vegetarian meals purchased by 40%. This increase was sustained over a year, even after taking into account the natural tendency of people to buy more vegetarian meals as they become more familiar with the new options. Our results suggest that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in catering outlets could have a significant impact on the environment. This approach could be easily implemented and has the potential to be scaled up rapidly.

The cell surface is the interface for the cell with the extracellular space. It is a dynamic and complex environment that is remodeled in cancer cells. Here we apply a quantitative proteomics approach to reveal how a collection of some 700 surface proteins is remodeled in a collection of isogenic breast epithelial cell lines stably expressing six of the most prominent oncogenes, including the receptor tyrosine kinases, EGFR and HER2, and downstream signaling partners such as KRAS, BRAF, MEK, and AKT. We find that each oncogene has somewhat different surfaceomes, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. In response to the COVID-19 pandemic, many scholars and policy makers are urging the United States to expand voting-by-mail programs to safeguard the electoral process. What are the effects of vote-by-mail? In this paper, we provide a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effect of universal vote-by-mail—a policy under which every voter is mailed a ballot in advance of the election—on electoral outcomes. We find that 1) universal vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, 2) universal vote-by-mail does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and 3) universal vote-by-mail modestly increases overall average turnout rates, in line with previous estimates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our findings suggest that vote-by-mail is a safe and effective way to conduct elections during the COVID-19 pandemic.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has had a devastating impact on the global community. The virus has spread rapidly, and the molecular basis for its spread and severity is largely unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which reveals a unique dimerization interface not seen in SARS-CoV. This dimerization interface is unique to SARS-CoV-2, and we hypothesize that it may be involved in immune evasion and/or spread. This structure provides a foundation for future studies of the role of ORF8 in the pandemic.

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can cause cerebral edema. However, the mechanisms underlying this process are not fully understood. Here we show that hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this process is mediated by the hypoxic-induced release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF), which acts on CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1) to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in cortical astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. These findings provide insights into the mechanisms underlying cerebral edema and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. This article is protected by copyright. The world is full of associations. We are interested in the ones that are “strong”—that is, that have a large effect size. But how do we assess the strength of an association? This is a problem of selective inference. We describe some recent developments in this area and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis.

The development of vascular ECs is a critical step for the formation of functional vascular networks. However, the minimum number of transcription factors that directly induce vascular ECs remains undefined. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) alone can induce the formation of functional vascular ECs. Our study provides a new strategy for the generation of vascular ECs and the formation of vascular networks. Furthermore, ETV2-induced vascular ECs can be used as a therapeutic tool for the treatment of vascular disorders. These findings may lead to the development of new strategies for the treatment of vascular disorders.

The receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) are a large family of transmembrane receptors that are involved in a variety of physiological processes. In the last few years, two new ligands have been discovered that bind to the RTKs and activate their signaling. These ligands are named augmentor-α1 and augmentor-α2 (also named “FAM150A” and “FAM150B,” respectively). Here, we show that these ligands are essential for zebrafish pigmentation. We also show that these ligands are not ligands for the RTKs in the context of the organism. These results establish a physiological link between the RTKs and augmentor ligands.

β-cell dysfunction is a major molecular basis for type 2 diabetes (T2D). The role of STING in β-cell function is unknown. Herein, we found that STING is decreased in islets of db/db mice and patients with T2D, suggesting a possible role of STING in β-cell dysfunction. Indeed, STING deficiency decreased expression of β-cell function–related genes, contributing to impaired GSIS. Mechanistically, the assay for transposase-accessible chromatin with high-throughput sequencing (ATAC-seq) and cleavage under targets and tagmentation (CUT&Tag) analyses suggested that Pax6 was the transcription factor that might be associated with defective GSIS in STING-βKO mice. Together, these data revealed a function of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and established pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. These findings may provide insights into the molecular mechanism of STING in the pathogenesis of T2D. This study may also provide a potential target for the treatment of T2D.

Influenza A viruses are the most important cause of human influenza. They cause annual epidemics and occasionally severe pandemics. The genome of influenza A viruses is segmented into eight fragments, which offers evolutionary advantages but complicates genomic packaging. The existence of a selective packaging mechanism, in which one copy of each viral RNA is specifically packaged into each virion, is suspected, but its molecular details remain unknown. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral genomic RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus. This interaction takes place in infected cells and is required for optimal viral replication. Disruption of this interaction decreased the amount of viral RNA in the viral particles, resulting in an eightfold increase in empty viral particles. This interaction is not widely conserved among influenza A viruses. The lack of conservation might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. Our results provide insights into the molecular mechanisms of viral genome packaging. They also have implications for the development of influenza vaccines and antiviral drugs. (Show more)

Atherosclerosis is a chronic inflammatory disease that leads to the development of cardiovascular diseases. The atheroprone hemodynamic environment is a key factor in the development of atherosclerosis. However, the mechanisms underlying the atheroprone hemodynamic environment remain largely unknown. In this study, we found that the activation of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) is involved in the atheroprone hemodynamic environment. Our results provide a molecular mechanism for the atheroprone hemodynamic environment and a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of atherosclerosis. Wildfire is a natural process that has been an integral part of the Earth system for millennia. However, human activities have increased the spatial and temporal extent of wildfire, and the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the geographic and seasonal extent of human-caused wildfires relative to lightning-caused wildfires. We show that human-caused wildfires have expanded the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire in the United States. Actions to reduce the risk of wildfire should be a priority for United States policy makers.

We use computer vision to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods over time. We find that the physical appearances of neighborhoods matter for their future physical change. Specifically, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Neighborhoods with better initial appearances are more likely to experience larger positive improvements. Neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, these results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also suggest that urban planners and policymakers should focus on improving the physical appearances of neighborhoods.

Natural repellents are a sustainable and ecofriendly pest control method. However, the molecular targets of these repellents in arthropod pests remain unknown. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities. The mechanisms of disease are not fully understood, but the within-host dynamics of ZIKV infection may play an important role. Here we present a mathematical model of ZIKV infection in a nonhuman primate model. We estimate the within-host dynamics of ZIKV infection, including the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We also assess the effect of an antiviral treatment on the time to undetectable plasma viral load. Our results can help guide the development of therapeutic strategies for ZIKV infection. Coral reefs are the most biologically diverse and valuable ecosystems on Earth. However, they are under threat from a variety of stressors, including climate change. The breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is one of the most severe consequences of this breakdown. We show that the metabolic interactions between coral and symbionts are a key factor in the early stages of this process. We demonstrate that the catabolism of amino acids during heat stress promotes the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates, thereby contributing to the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis. This process is driven by altered nutrient cycling, which is a consequence of the metabolic stress imposed by heat stress. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may help us to better predict the fate of coral reefs in a changing climate. The intestinal epithelium is a critical barrier that protects the host from the environment. In the case of cancer, the epithelium becomes leaky and allows the dissemination of cancer cells to other organs. Here, we show that the intestinal tumor microenvironment can alter the composition of the microbiome, which in turn can promote tumor growth. We also show that the tumor microenvironment can be modulated to restore the integrity of the intestinal barrier and the host–microbiome homeostasis. Our work highlights the importance of controlling the activity of the JNK pathway to maintain intestinal barrier function and host–microbiome homeostasis. These findings have implications for cancer treatment and for the development of new strategies to control the intestinal microbiome. They also highlight the importance of controlling the activity of the JNK pathway to maintain intestinal barrier function and host–microbiome homeostasis. These findings have implications for cancer treatment and for the development of new strategies to control the intestinal microbiome.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, but resistance to chemotherapy is a major problem. In this study, we found that the expression of the type I tyrosine kinase-like orphan receptor ROR1 increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy. We also found that ROR1 enhanced the capacity of breast cancer cells to metastasize and reengraft mice. Finally, we found that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts (PDXs) with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab repressed expression of genes associated with breast cancer stemness, reduced activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1, and impaired the capacity of breast cancer PDXs to metastasize or reengraft mice. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. Thus, our results may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for breast cancer. This study may also lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for other cancers. The timing of the start of accelerated deglaciation is controversial, with some studies suggesting that deglaciation began as early as 18.0 ka and others suggesting that deglaciation only accelerated at 17.7 ka. We show that the start of accelerated deglaciation is linked to a unique volcanic event, the Mount Takahe eruptions, which led to stratospheric ozone depletion and a poleward shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies. These changes are consistent with the start of accelerated deglaciation. This study provides a unique example of how volcanic eruptions can influence climate and the timing of deglaciation. This is important because the timing of deglaciation is a key control on the amount of time that carbon is stored in ice sheets and the timing of sea-level rise. Understanding the timing of deglaciation is therefore critical for understanding the future rate of sea-level rise. This study also highlights the importance of volcanic eruptions in the Southern Hemisphere, which are often overlooked in climate studies. This is important because the Southern Hemisphere is the dominant source of greenhouse gases and climate change. The Southern Hemisphere also has a large and growing population, which is vulnerable to climate change.

Freshwater fisheries are an important source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people worldwide. However, they are often overlooked in global assessments of fisheries and biodiversity. We derive a global map of riverine fisheries and use it to assess the role of inland fisheries in food security, biodiversity conservation, and fishery sustainability. We find that river fisheries provide the equivalent of all global dietary animal protein for 158 million people, and that poor and undernourished populations are particularly reliant on inland fisheries. Our analysis also reveals that fishing pressure is most intense in regions where rivers are already degraded by other stressors. This “double jeopardy” of high fishing pressure and low biodiversity underscores the need for improved management of inland fisheries. Our data can be used to inform environmental planning to protect both food security and species diversity.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge. The energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited in aqueous Li-ion batteries due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material (i.e., LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2) is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The unique nanosized and metastable character of the material is the key to achieve high energy density and safety. This work combines a high capacity with a safe negative electrode material through delivering the Mo-based oxide with unique nanosized and metastable characters. The work provides a new strategy for the development of high-energy and safe aqueous batteries. This work is expected to promote the development of aqueous energy storage devices. The ability to regenerate after injury is a defining feature of the nervous system. In the adult mammalian CNS, however, neurons are largely incapable of regenerating after injury. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is remarkably independent of the MAPK signaling pathway, which is known to mediate regeneration in the adult CNS. This form of regeneration is triggered by physical lesion of the neuron and is dependent on a form of activity-dependent ectopic axon outgrowth. These findings suggest that the mechanisms that control endogenous axon outgrowth may be a powerful platform for gene discovery in the study of neuronal regeneration. Moreover, our study suggests that the adult mammalian CNS may be more plastic than previously thought, and that the ability to regenerate may be more widespread than previously appreciated.

Recombination is the process by which DNA is broken and then rejoined in a random fashion. It is essential for the proper development of the genome and is the primary mechanism by which genetic variation is generated. In this paper, we describe the distribution of recombination across the genome of a flowering plant, Mimulus guttatus. We find that recombination is concentrated in hotspots, which are interspersed with cold regions. The distribution of hotspots is similar to that observed in yeast and in mice. These results provide a detailed view of the distribution of recombination across a flowering plant genome. They may help us understand the evolution of recombination in eukaryotes.

The resting brain is a dynamic system, with fluctuations in blood oxygen level-dependent (BOLD) signal representing the activity of a small fraction of total neuronal activity. The analysis of these fluctuations has led to the identification of networks of nodes (brain regions) and edges (correlations) in the brain, which are hypothesized to reflect functional properties of the brain. Here, we used a different approach, which measures the total activity of the brain, to identify and validate reproducible resting state networks in healthy and disease populations. We found that the dominant resting state network in healthy subjects was topographically similar to the default mode network. In contrast, in Parkinson’s disease, this dominant network was subordinated to an independent disease-related pattern. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying the expression of the resting state networks in rest and during task performance. We found that the dominant resting state network was deactivated during task performance, and that this abnormality was partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. This study provides a new approach to the study of the resting brain.

RNA modifications are important for gene expression regulation. Here we report the discovery of a 5′ nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) cap in yeast. We show that this cap is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs. We also show that this cap is not found on pre-mRNAs that are 5′ end processed. This 5′ NAD+ cap may have a role in regulating mRNA stability and translation.

Metabolic memory is the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy on the progression of microvascular complications in people with diabetes. We show that DNA methylation at specific loci in blood cells is associated with glycemia for several years during the EDIC Study. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory. This study also provides a resource for future studies on the role of DNA methylation in the pathogenesis of diabetes complications.

Fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) is a cancer antigen expressed in the majority of breast cancer tissues and is associated with poor prognosis. However, the role of FSIP1 in the progression and drug sensitivity of triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. This article is protected by copyright. Alcohol dependence is a complex disorder with a high rate of relapse. The present study suggests that the gut microbiota may be involved in the development of alcohol dependence. We found that some, but not all, alcohol-dependent subjects developed gut leakiness, which was associated with higher scores of depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving after 3 wk of abstinence. Moreover, subjects with increased gut permeability also had altered composition and activity of the gut microbiota. These results suggest the existence of a gut–brain axis in alcohol dependence, which implicates the gut microbiota as an actor in the gut barrier and in behavioral disorders. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. This study may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for alcohol dependence. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Tomato fruit are a major source of flavor for human consumption. The production of a wide range of volatile compounds during fruit ripening is essential for the development of fruit aroma. However, the biosynthetic pathways of many of these compounds are unknown. We report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes the formation of the nitrogenous moiety in these compounds. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of tomato fruit flavor. It also opens the door to the development of new strategies for the production of other nitrogenous flavor compounds. (Show more)

Biodiversity loss and global warming are two of the most profound threats to the functional integrity of the Earth’s ecosystems. However, these factors are most frequently investigated separately, ignoring the potential for synergistic effects. Here we use high-throughput experiments to investigate how changes in temperature affect the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. We found that changes in temperature systematically altered the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. As temperatures departed from ambient conditions, the exponent of the diversity-functioning relationship increased, meaning that more species were required to maintain ecosystem functioning under thermal stress. This key result was driven by two processes linked to variability in the thermal tolerance curves of taxa. Our results highlight that if biodiversity loss occurs independently of species’ thermal tolerance traits, then the additional impacts of environmental warming will result in sharp declines in ecosystem function. Our findings have important implications for the design of biodiversity conservation strategies and the management of ecosystems under climate change. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for navigation. It encodes the spatial layout of the environment, including the location of the animal and the direction of its heading. The organization of MEC is not fully understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of neurons in MEC during free-moving behavior. We found that grid cells, which encode the animal’s location, are anatomically segregated from border, head-direction, and object-vector cells, which encode the animal’s heading. These data provide a detailed view of the organization of MEC and its relation to navigation. They also provide a powerful tool for studying the organization of the MEC in the future.

Flowering is a complex process that is controlled by a number of genes. In this study, we show that the FLOWERING LOCUS T (FT) gene is not the only gene that is involved in flowering regulation. We show that FTs can function as an important interplant flowering signal in host–dodder interactions. The unique means of flowering regulation of dodder illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness. This study provides a new perspective on the evolution of flowering and flowering regulation. It also provides a new approach to study the evolution of flowering regulation. This study may also have implications for the study of flowering in general.

The dopamine system of the brain powerfully influences movement and motivation. We show that striatonigral fibers originating in striosomes form highly unusual bouquet-like arborizations that target bundles of ventrally extending dopamine-containing dendrites and clusters of their parent nigral cell bodies. These clustered cell bodies in turn project to the striatum as part of the classic nigrostriatal pathway. Thus, these striosome–dendron bouquets likely represent subsystems with the nigro–striato–nigral loop that are affected in human disorders including Parkinson’s disease. Given evidence that striosomes receive input from cortical regions related to the control of mood and motivation and that they link functionally to reinforcement and decision-making, the striosome–dendron bouquets could be critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease. This study provides a unique view of the organization of the dopamine-containing nigral system. It also suggests that the bouquet–dendron formation is a general feature of the striatonigral system. This may have implications for the organization of other corticostriatal systems. The study may also have implications for the organization of other corticostriatal systems.

We are social creatures, and we often judge the quality of our social interactions by how well we feel connected to our partners. We show that the speed with which we respond to others is a robust predictor of how connected we feel. This response time signal is used by others to judge the quality of our interactions, and it is used by us to signal to others how connected we feel. Together, these findings suggest that we are constantly assessing the quality of our social interactions, and we are constantly being assessed by others.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. It is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, which are responsible for generating the heart rate. The SAN is a highly coordinated system that is able to adjust heart rate to meet hemodynamic demand. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a key regulator of the heart rate in the SAN. We show that STIM1 is selectively expressed in the specialized cardiomyocytes of the SAN, and that its deletion in mice leads to a reduction in the number of sarcoplasmic reticulum Ca2+ stores in these cells. This leads to a reduction in the heart rate and to an exaggerated autonomic response. These results reveal a previously unknown role for STIM1 in Ca2+ dynamics in the SAN. They also suggest that STIM1 may be a target for the treatment of heart rate disorders. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development. However, its role in plant defense against insect herbivores has been controversial. Here, we show that Si pretreatment enhances resistance against the rice leaffolder in rice plants, which is associated with increased levels of jasmonic acid (JA), defense gene expression, and Si accumulation. These results suggest that Si and JA may interact in plant defense against insect herbivores. This study provides a better understanding of the role of Si in plant defense. (Show more)

Tetrahydrobiopterin is a cofactor that is essential for nitric oxide synthesis and aromatic amino acid hydroxylation. It is used to treat phenylketonuria. Less is known about the role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase are important regulators of ether lipid metabolism in murine macrophages. We demonstrate that the expression of alkylglycerol monooxygenase is important for the activation of macrophages and that it has a profound impact on the lipidome. Our results reveal a central role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism of murine macrophages. They also suggest that alteration of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity has a profound impact on the lipidome beyond the class of ether lipids. This may have implications for the regulation of macrophage activation.

Language is a complex system that requires the integration of information over time. The brain is thought to accomplish this through the maintenance of information in the form of elevated neural activity. Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on the adaptive modulation of neuronal excitability. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can bind information over time. We show that this mechanism can support the binding of linguistic features within a sequence of words. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Plants are sessile organisms and are unable to move to avoid toxic stimuli. Thus, they are dependent on their environment for survival. One of the major challenges in plant biology is to deliver functional molecules to plants for the purpose of gene regulation. Herein, we report the delivery of functional molecules to plants using DNA nanostructures. We show that DNA nanostructures can be used to deliver siRNAs to plants and that the gene silencing efficiency depends on the DNA nanostructure geometry. Our work establishes the feasibility of delivering functional molecules to plants and also details the design parameters of importance for gene silencing mechanisms. This work will be useful for the plant biology community and will help in the development of new strategies for gene regulation in plants.

Nutrient loading from small tributaries is often overlooked in assessments of watershed nutrient sources. We show that small tributaries can be a significant source of nutrients to large water bodies. We found that small tributaries delivered ∼20% of the daily nutrient loads to Lake Michigan, but they were more likely to deliver dissolved inorganic nutrients, which are more bioavailable to algae. This suggests that nutrient loading from small tributaries may be more important than previously thought for fueling algal blooms in nearshore areas of large water bodies. Our findings highlight the importance of small tributaries as a source of nutrients to coastal ecosystems and provide a framework for future research on the role of small tributaries in nutrient loading to large water bodies.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is biased toward rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the behavior of a mechanical system that is biased toward rare configurations of its degrees of freedom. We discuss the implications of our results for the study of complex systems that are biased toward rare configurations.

The mechanisms underlying the paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in patients with autoimmune encephalitis are poorly understood. Here we show that NMDAR-Abs can change the intrinsic microcircuitry of the brain, leading to changes in the spectral composition of spontaneous EEG activity. We use a dynamic causal model to identify the key synaptic parameters that best explain the EEG paroxysms in patients with NMDAR-Ab encephalitis. Finally, we show that these changes in microcircuitry can lead to overt EEG paroxysms when the same parameter fluctuations are tolerated in a model of the control condition. These findings offer mechanistic insights into the circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Abs. The history of abrupt climate change is a key component of the Earth system. However, the history of abrupt climate change is poorly understood because of the difficulty in identifying and quantifying these events. Here, we present a case study of an abrupt climate change event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that this event was associated with a doubling of atmospheric CO2 and a biodiversity nadir. We also show that this event was linked to an increase in organic matter burial and anoxia. These results provide insights into the history of abrupt climate change and the Earth system. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the most widely used certification scheme for palm oil. We show that certification reduces deforestation in oil palm plantations. However, certification has little impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our results suggest that certification may be a useful tool for reducing deforestation in oil palm, but that it is not a panacea.

The exocyst complex is a conserved protein complex that regulates the last steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. In humans, its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. The exocyst complex is evolutionarily conserved, and its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. Investigation of the dynamic regulation of the exocyst-related processes using mutants in genetically tractable organisms such as Arabidopsis thaliana is limited by the lethality or the severity of phenotypes. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 (exocyst component of 70 kDa) subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and offers a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a fundamental process in biology, and the sex of an organism is often a key factor in its survival and reproduction. In vertebrates, sex is determined by a single gene in most species, but in others, multiple genes interact to produce the sex of the organism. Here we investigate the effects of multiple interacting sex determination alleles in a fish species, where one sex determination allele is female-specific and the other is male-specific. We find that this system produces modular variation in secondary sexual characteristics, which can be used to understand the evolutionary causes and consequences of sex determination alleles in populations.

The retina is challenged by the accumulation of bisretinoids, a class of oxidized carotenoids that are formed by the oxidation of the molecule A2E. The oxidation of A2E is catalyzed by light and reactive oxygen species. We show that the accumulation of bisretinoids is reduced in mice with reduced levels of intracellular iron. This reduction is mediated by the chelator deferiprone, which increases intracellular iron levels. These findings have implications for the pathogenesis of age-related macular degeneration, a leading cause of blindness in the elderly. They also suggest that the oxidation of A2E may be a target for the treatment of this disease. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of iron in the formation of the damaging species that contribute to the loss of photoreceptor cells in age-related macular degeneration. It also provides a rationale for the use of deferiprone in the treatment of this disease. (Read more)

Predators are the foundation of most food webs, and the evolution of predator specialization has been considered an evolutionary dead end. However, in some predators, prey capture is localized in separate structures. One of the most extreme cases of this modularity can be observed in the pelagic siphonophores, a group of cnidarians that use tentilla (tentacle side branches armed with nematocysts) exclusively for prey capture. We show that siphonophore specialists can evolve into generalists, and that specialists on one prey type have directly evolved into specialists on other prey types. Our findings help build a broader perspective on predatory niche diversification via morphological innovation and evolution. These findings contribute to understanding how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs.

The evolution of the human hand is a key topic in human evolutionary biology. The earliest hominin fossils are incomplete, and the time interval between the appearance of the first hominids and the emergence of the distinctive derived features of the modern human hand is poorly documented. We report the discovery of a hominin hand fossil from East Africa that preserves the third metacarpal styloid process, a key derived feature of the modern human hand. This fossil provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of this key derived feature of the human hand. The timing of the evolution of this feature suggests that it arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo. This finding has implications for our understanding of the evolution of the human hand and its relationship to the Neandertal hand. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Cancer is a disease of rapid cell growth. One-carbon units are required for cell growth, and are provided by the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT). Here we show that dual knockout of SHMT1 and SHMT2 in cancer cells blocks tumor growth. We also identify a small-molecule inhibitor of SHMT1/2, which is effective in cancer cells and in cancer cell-line screens. Finally, we show that one-carbon donor formate is a potent rescue of SHMT inhibition in cancer cells, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in a cancer cell line that is uniquely dependent upon SHMT enzymatic activity for glycine import. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of cancer cells. This work provides a rationale for targeting SHMT in cancer. It also provides a platform for the development of a small-molecule cancer drug that is effective in a broad range of cancer cell types. This is a significant advance in the development of cancer therapeutics.

The world is facing a double burden of malnutrition, with a growing number of people suffering from both undernutrition and micronutrient deficiencies. In low- and middle-income countries, forests are often overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, despite the fact that forests can provide people with access to a variety of foods that are rich in micronutrients. This study shows that deforestation can have negative impacts on people’s diets and micronutrient adequacy, and that this is likely to be the case in many other settings. This study has important implications for policy makers, who should consider the role of forests in improving people’s diets and nutrition.

Modern agriculture is a major contributor to global food production, but it is also responsible for the loss of soil productivity. We show that the increase in mechanization has led to the propagation of subsoil compaction into deeper soil layers. This has the potential to reduce soil productivity and has been exacerbated by the increase in vehicle weight. We propose that the design of farm machinery should consider intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. This may help to reduce subsoil compaction and improve soil productivity.
